relationships.evidence: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) commonly used to treat major depressive disorder.
Sertraline is an SSRI indicated for the treatment of major depressive disorder.
Paroxetine is an SSRI used to treat major depressive disorder.
Citalopram is an SSRI effective in treating major depressive disorder.
Escitalopram is an SSRI used for major depressive disorder.
Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used for major depressive disorder.
Duloxetine is an SNRI indicated for major depressive disorder.
Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant used for major depressive disorder.
Mirtazapine is an antidepressant used for major depressive disorder.
Ketamine is used for treatment-resistant depression.
ECT is a somatic therapy effective for major depressive disorder.
CBT is a psychotherapy method used to treat major depressive disorder.
IPT is a psychotherapy method for major depressive disorder.
rTMS is a neuromodulation technique used for major depressive disorder.
tDCS is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique for major depressive disorder.
DBS is used for treatment-resistant depression.
Psychodynamic therapy is a treatment approach for major depressive disorder.

interactions.note: Both fluoxetine and sertraline affect serotonin levels.
interactions.evidence: Both are SSRIs and may increase the risk of serotonin syndrome when combined.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and paroxetine both affect serotonin levels.
interactions.evidence: Combining SSRIs can increase the risk of serotonin syndrome.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and citalopram both affect serotonin levels.
interactions.evidence: Increased risk of serotonin syndrome when combined.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and escitalopram both affect serotonin levels.
interactions.evidence: Increased risk of serotonin syndrome when combined.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and venlafaxine both affect serotonin and norepinephrine.
interactions.evidence: Potential for increased side effects due to overlapping mechanisms.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and duloxetine both affect serotonin and norepinephrine.
interactions.evidence: Potential for increased side effects due to overlapping mechanisms.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and bupropion may have opposing effects on serotonin.
interactions.evidence: Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and mirtazapine may have additive sedative effects.
interactions.evidence: Mirtazapine can cause sedation, which may be enhanced by fluoxetine.

interactions.note: Fluoxetine and ketamine may have additive effects on serotonin.
interactions.evidence: Both can influence serotonin levels, increasing the risk of serotonin syndrome.
